title: How to Know if Hair Dye Is Expired

steps.title: Inspect the package for an expiration date.
steps.content: Inspect the package for an expiration date. Some hair dyes come with a “best by” or “use before” date, which helps you know if your dye is expired. Check the side of the package—if you find an expired date, toss out the product. [3] X Research source A lot of beauty companies don’t include a freshness date on their products, so this might not be a feasible option. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Toss out pre-opened dyes after a year.
steps.content: Toss out pre-opened dyes after a year. Opened dye doesn’t go bad right away—instead, it will last about 1 year before expiring. If you opened your dye more than a year ago or can’t quite remember when you first used it, throw out the product to be safe. [5] X Research source If you can’t remember when you purchased or opened the dye, consider getting new hair dye altogether.

steps.title: Hold onto unopened dye for 2-3 years.
steps.content: Hold onto unopened dye for 2-3 years. If you’ve had your dye for longer, toss it out and pick up a new product from your local beauty shop. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Toss out dyes that were stored in a sunny, hot area.
steps.content: Toss out dyes that were stored in a sunny, hot area. Peroxide and ammonia are common chemicals found in most hair dyes. Unfortunately, both of these chemicals create an unpleasant chemical reaction when they’re exposed to high heat. Examine your storage area—if it’s consistently over 75 °F (24 °C), toss out the dye and pick up something new. [7] X Research source This chemical reaction causes the dye to separate, which isn’t good. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Throw out the dye if it's leaking.
steps.content: Throw out the dye if it's leaking. Hold the bottle and tip it upside-down to ensure there are no leaks. If the bottle is leaky, you can assume that the dye has gone bad, and throw it out. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Inspect the packaging for dents, damage, wet spots, or fading.
steps.content: Inspect the packaging for dents, damage, wet spots, or fading. Dents, moisture, and other outer damage can spell bad news for hair dye. If your hair dye packaging looks damp or worse for wear, throw it out and use a new product. [10] X Research source Sometimes, dye bottles will look lumpy or swollen because of bad chemical reactions.

steps.title: It has a strange or foul odor.
steps.content: It has a strange or foul odor. Does the dye smell very metallic, or just rotten overall? If so, you can assume the dye is expired. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Study the dye color to see if it resembles the correct color.
steps.content: Study the dye color to see if it resembles the correct color. The dye should look like its respective shade, and not look like a completely different shade. [12] X Research source

steps.title: It’s separated into a milky fluid.
steps.content: It’s separated into a milky fluid. Open up the dye and see if the dye is smooth, or it’s already separated. If you see the telltale milky liquid, get rid of the dye. [13] X Research source Dyes don’t have to be in a cracked, leaky container to separate. Your dye bottle might be completely intact, but the product could still be separated.

steps.title: A mixed batch is bright- or light-colored.
steps.content: A mixed batch is bright- or light-colored. After it's mixed, a proper dye will look a bit lighter than the desired shade. If the color is already a deep shade, you can assume that it’s expired. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse out dye immediately if it burns when you apply.
steps.content: Rinse out dye immediately if it burns when you apply. Hair dye should never hurt when you apply it to your hair. If your scalp burns after you apply the dye, rinse out the product and throw out any of the old dye. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Check for an abnormal tint in your recently-dyed hair.
steps.content: Check for an abnormal tint in your recently-dyed hair. When a dye expires, the product loses its original quality. Because of this, your hair may tint in an undesired shade. [16] X Research source Examine your hair after you’ve dyed it—if the dye is tinted green or some other unwanted shade, you can assume that the dye is expired. [17] X Research source For example, some brown hair dyes are made with red pigment. If the dye is expired, your hair might look red instead of brown. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Watch for hair color that fades quickly after application.
steps.content: Watch for hair color that fades quickly after application. Check the dye label to see how long the color is supposed to last. If the color is fading really quickly, there’s a good chance that the dye you used was expired. [19] X Research source For instance, if your dye should last a month but fades after 2 weeks, the dye was probably past its prime. Sometimes, expired dye simply won’t work, leaving your hair the same color it originally was. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Feel your hair to see if it’s coarse or frizzy after dyeing it.
steps.content: Feel your hair to see if it’s coarse or frizzy after dyeing it. While it isn’t very common, expired hair dye can occasionally lead to frizzy and damaged hair. [21] X Expert Source April Ferri Professional Hair Stylist Expert Interview. 8 December 2020. Check your hair after you’ve applied the dye—if it’s looking broken, then your old dye might have been expired. [22] X Research source
